Public Member Functions
Signal::EventPhy Class Reference

Class for bridging physical events with Signal events. More...

#include <Signal.hpp>

Inheritance diagram for Signal::EventPhy:
Collaboration diagram for Signal::EventPhy:

Detailed Description

This class allows you to configure physical events to trigger signals. For example, a rising edge on a pin can cause the system to send a signal to a thread. Here is an example:

#include <applib/Signal.hpp>
#include <applib/Timer.hpp>
volatile bool my_var;
void my_handler(int a){
//this executes on the rising edge of EINT0
my_var = true;
//you shouldn't use any non re-entrant functions here (such as printf() and malloc())
}
int main(int argc, char * argv[]){
Eint eint(0);
eint_action_t action;
Signal::EventPhy phy_event(true, SIGUSR1); //send SIGUSR1 to this thread on every rising edge
Signal::Handler handler(my_handler);
eint.init(0);
phy_event.set_handler(&handler);
//this configures the hardware to send the signal to this thread (my_handler() will execute)
//phy_event MUST exist as long as this action is set
action = phy_event.action(EINT_ACTION_EVENT_RISING);
eint.setaction( &action );
while(my_var == false){
Timer::wait_sec(1);
}
return 0;
}

int  signo,
int  sigcode = 0,
int  sigvalue = 0 
)
inline

This constructs a physical event.

Parameters
persistantIf false, the signal will be sent only on the first hardware event
signoThe signal number
sigcodeThe signal code
sigvalueThe signal value
Signal::EventPhy::EventPhy ( signal_callback_t  context)
inline

Construct a physical event using a signal_callback_t data structure.

Parameters
contextA copy of the signal_callback_t data to use to handle the event.

Member Function Documentation

int  channel = 0 
)

This returns a hwpl_action_t data structure that can be used to set the action associated with a hardware event.
